channel.title: Code on Strange Labs Computers
channel.description: Recent content in Code on Strange Labs Computers

item.title: Integrating Distributed Data Environments
item.description: Abstract The concept of Common Data Environments (CDEs) has undergone significant evolution since its inception within the Architecture, Engineering, and Construction (AEC) industries. Initially conceived as centralised platforms for collaborative data management, CDEs have expanded beyond their original scope to encompass broader team-based data sharing across various sectors. This article examines the transformation of CDEs from single-platform solutions to distributed systems, exploring the challenges that emerge when multiple teams require independent CDEs and the subsequent integration complexities.

item.title: Designing A Space For Technology Enthusiasts
item.description: Introduction From 2017 to 2020, I embarked on an exciting project to transform my traditional PC repair shop into a dynamic social space where programmers could meet, collaborate, and work on projects. Midway through this transformation, I shared an update on the progress. Now, as we close the chapter on this journey, Iâ€™m reflecting on the design process and what we achieved. For the final look before closing, be sure to check out the photos at the end.

item.title: Arguing For Open Source
item.description: Why Should We Trust What People Hide from Us? Open source technology holds the potential to build greater trust among people. By extending the principles of open source from computer science to other areas of society and culture, we might unlock significant benefits. What is open source? At its core, open source refers to software whose source code, the underlying instructions that define how the software functions, is freely available for anyone to view, modify, and redistribute.
